input.description: XML document conforming to the Connection Details Concept that contains the information required to execute a command via command line.
Interface name. On SunOS use only the interface name. Interface index is the driver path, eg. /dev/bge0.

output.description: XML document consisting of one or more <line> elements that contain the command response. Each <line> element contains an index attribute indicating the order in which the information was returned by the command.
Did the operation Succeed? Valid value: true.

xslt-stylesheet.stylesheet: <xsl:stylesheet xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" version="1.0"> <xsl:output indent="yes" /> <xsl:template match="/"> <fat-command> <command os-id="Cisco IOS"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no">show </xsl:text> </command> <command os-id="Windows Default"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no">echo Command not supported on Windows.</xsl:text> </command> <command os-id="Linux"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no">/bin/echo Command not supported on Linux.</xsl:text> </command> <command os-id="SunOS"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no">/usr/sbin/ndd -get </xsl:text> <xsl:if test="string-length('${index}')!=0"> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> ${index}</xsl:text> <xsl:text disable-output-escaping="no"> link_status</xsl:text> </xsl:if> </command> </fat-command> </xsl:template> </xsl:stylesheet>

documentation.description: This process uses ndd to get the interface status parameter in the kernel interface drivers. Currently, ndd only supports the drivers that implement the TCP/IP Internet protocol family. Each driver chooses which parameters to make visible using ndd. This process was designed to work with Solaris only.
